project_settings.name: MEDEVAC Mission Network (MMN)
project_settings.background: The MEDEVAC Mission Network (MMN) is taken from the concept of the Afghan Mission Network (AMN) where MEDEVAC was an integral service of the AMN. In this project, we create an example of a SoS for testing of certain SoS elements relevant to security and risk assessment in SoSs.
project_settings.strategic_goals: The SoS goal is to provide a medical evacuation continuum of care.
project_settings.scope: The scope of this project is to consider a reduced-scale exemplar of a medical evacuation continuum of care. This example is based on published information and accurate in context. However, for testing purposes, the scenario has been reduced and takes key elements and roles within the SoS management and operation. Some software and hardware combinations have also been reallocated across the SoS to suit available data for the scenario. Moreover, the MEDEVAC scenario considers care given to a casualty at Point of Injury, who is taken by Air MEDEVAC to Forward Surgical Team for initial hospital care. The scenario does not include further transportation and care to HQ, Mid-Point, or Home hospitals.

entry.name: System
entry.definition: Systems can be described as 'a coming together of people, process, software and hardware, integrated to achieve a purpose'. Systems are likely to be decomposed of supporting sub-systems and component systems interconnecting to fulfil system needs.

entry.name: System of Systems
entry.definition:
We can simply define a System of Systems as being 'the coming together of independent systems collaborating for a new or higher purpose'.
Collaboration must be in place by one means or another for the SoS to exist, otherwise they would simply be independent systems. Although Evolution is a likely catalyst of a SoS, Operational and Managerial levels of independence and control throughout the SoS are most critical for SoS characterisation. Emergent behaviour may arise from SoS evolution. However, Geography and Evolution are equally applicable to modern systems and less specific to SoSs.

asset.name: 9-Line Request
asset.description: A call for Forward Air MEDEVAC is usually initiated by a 9-Line request, providing a nine line template of minimum information related to patient, location and evacuation requirements.
asset.significance: (line 1) Location of pickup site, (See task 071-329-1006, Navigate From One Point on the Ground to Another While Dismounted.), (line 2) Radio frequency, call sign, and suffix, (See task 113-305-1001, Communicate by a Tactical Radio.),(line 3) Number of patients by precedence, (line 4) Special equipment required, (line 5) Number of patients by type, (line 6) Security of pickup site, (line 7) Method of marking pickup site, (line 8) Patient nationality and status, (line 9) NBC contamination.

security_property.rationale: In most cases, the request including its location should be confidential and use encrypted communications where required.
The request should be audible and clear, and uninterrupted.
The ability to transmit and receive this information is critical in an emergency scenario.
(Bravo) has accountability to clear and correct communications, whereas others have accountability to acknowledge and react to the request.

asset.name: B-F1 - FMC-TCCC - Patient Info
asset.description: In most cases medics would complete a Field Medical Card or a Tactical Combat Casualty Card (FMC - TCCC). This details basic required information relating to the patient, injuries, care and medication, and other related data. The FMC will be produced in a water resistant material that can be written or drawn upon with a likewise water resistant pencil or the like. The FMC is to be initially used by the first responder and follow the casualty en route.
asset.significance: In most cases medics would complete a Field Medical Card or a Tactical Combat Casualty Card (FMC - TCCC). This details basic required information relating to the patient, injuries, care and medication, and other related data. The FMC will be produced in a water resistant material that can be written or drawn upon with a likewise water resistant pencil or the like. The FMC is to be initially used by the first responder and follow the casualty en route. A copy is usually retained by the medic, but is also transfered out of (Bravo) boundaries through and too (Alpha and Charlie). The availability and integrity of this information is vital to continuation of patient care.

security_property.rationale: The data is produced by a medic about a patient. This information is usually past along with the patient via an air medic and on to the FST, and other stage hospitals when required, but should be accessed only by relevant staff proving patient care.
Integrity of the data must be maintained to ensure correct patient information is clear and recordable.
In some cases a FMC - TCCC may not be completed due to time constraints. However, where this is used, it is very useful towards accurate accounting of initial and continuing care.

Bravo is responsible for the creation and retention of a copy of the FMC - TCCC information. However, continuing care providers Charlie have accountability towards maintaining its on-going PST, where Alpha have accountability towards the operational network data is shared within.

asset.description: The Medic has first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information may be transferred and written to a FMC-TCCC, input on a mobile handset, be verbally transmitted via radio communications and in-person to Air Medics.
asset.significance: The Medic has first-hand knowledge of patient care. Without the availability and transfer of this information, patient care may be affected.

asset.name: C-F1 - Air Medic - Patient Info
asset.description: In addition to Field Medic patient info, the Air Medic will have first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information is likely to include a written FMC-TCCC, and verbal field medic communication, and further continuing care information.
asset.significance: In addition to Field Medic patient info, the Air Medic will have first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information is likely to include a written FMC-TCCC, and verbal field medic communication. Continuing care information is transferred verbally to the FST Technician and entered on to the MC4 Theater system. Without the availability and transfer of this information, patient care may be affected, and health records may become incorrect.

asset.name: A - Mission TOC
asset.description: A NATO Mission Tactical Operations Centre (TOC) co-ordinates operations within a RC with FOBs.
asset.significance: A NATO Mission Tactical Operations Centre (TOC) co-ordinates operations within a RC with FOBs.

asset.name: A - PECC
asset.description: A NATO Patient Evacuation Co-ordination Cell (PECC) is the key to the coordination of movements of the patients. Each component of an operation will have at least one PECC (they may have more to ensure regional cover). They receive the patient movement requests which include the details necessary to ensure the most effective movement such as medical priority (P1, P2, P3) and this is coordinated with transport means available within their area of responsibility. In critical situations the PECC will often serve as the medical CJOC.

asset.name: B-F1 - MC4 Mobile Field System
asset.description: The MC4 Mobile Field System contains a mobile handset using Android OS, and a range of software including AHLTA-Mobile. FMC-TCCC information can be added and uploaded to AHLTA-Theater adding to the patient EHR.
asset.significance: The MC4 Mobile Field System contains a mobile handset using Android OS, and a range of software including AHLTA-Mobile. FMC-TCCC information can be added and uploaded to AHLTA-Theater adding to the patient EHR. Availability of the system is required, although integrity of data is important and confidentiality in storage and transmission.

asset.name: C-F2 - FST MC4 Theater System
asset.description: The MC4 Theater System contains peripherals, a mobile laptop using Windows OS, and a range of software including AHLTA-Theater. FMC-TCCC and other related medical information can be added and uploaded to AHLTA-Theater adding to the patient EHR.
asset.significance: The MC4 Theater System contains peripherals, a mobile laptop using Windows OS, and a range of software including AHLTA-Theater. FMC-TCCC and other related medical information can be added and uploaded to AHLTA-Theater adding to the patient EHR. Availability of the system is important, although integrity of data is important and confidentiality in storage and transmission.

asset.name: A - TMDS
asset.description: Data is sent to the Theater Medical Data Store (TMDS) becoming part of a patient’s long-term Electronic Health Record (EHR). Data is also transferred to the Department of Defense (DoD) Clinical Data Repository (CDR), accessible to authorised personnel worldwide.
asset.significance: Key Features: Capability to view, track, and manage ill or injured patients as they move through Theater levels of care, sustaining-base MTFs, and facilities shared with VA Ability to access Theater medical data and pass medical data to the Clinical Data Repository. Services-oriented architecture. Interface for benefits assessment. Shares information with command and control systems for medical situation awareness. Key Benefits: Allows VA to access Theater medical data for a patient who has entered a VA medical facility. Provides central location for all medical data generated in Theater…integrated into the electronic health record. Key Issues: Training, Awareness.

asset.name: A - TC2
asset.description: TMIP Composite Health Care System (CHCS) Cache (TC2) is an inpatient documentation solution. Provides documentation for Theater inpatient healthcare and ancillary services order entry and result-reporting in the deployed environment.
asset.significance: Key Features: Provides laboratory, radiology and pharmacy ordering and results retrieval capabilities; enables users to schedule outpatient clinic/radiology procedures. Uses the TMIP Framework for transmission of data to TMDS. Clinical Notes for different procedures including admission, discharge and patient progress, transportable Clinical Patient Records. TC2 has processed 48,129 total records from June 2007 to present. Key Benefits: Enhanced Inpatient and Ancillary Continuity of Care. Enables the Deployed Theater to achieve a paperless Inpatient Record. Increased clinical and administration efficiency by providing clinical documentation capabilities. Key Issues: Training, Business Processes.

asset.name: A - TRAC2ES
asset.description: TRANSCOM Regulating and Command and Control System (TRAC2ES) is a global patient movement solution. Enables joint global patient movement, planning, tracking and Command and Control (C2) within (intra) and between (inter) theaters.
asset.significance: Key Features: Links originating and destination MTFs with medical evacuation transportation assets and the C2 infrastructure. Provides the ability to plan and manage end to end patient movement. Supports strategic and tactical operations in peacetime and contingency environments. Key Benefits: Maintains continuous global visibility and awareness of patients and the patient movement system. In transit visibility (ITV). Combines transportation, logistics and clinical decision elements into seamless patient movement system. Key Issues: Not an EHR. Enroute Care Documentation.

asset.name: A - JMeWS
asset.description: Joint Medical Workstation (JMeWS) is a web-based medical command and control. Continued support for medical command and control (C2) requirements with JMeWS.
asset.significance: Key Features: Web-based application that provides medical information and unit status and readiness to medical leadership from the unit level to the Joint Task Force, Combatant Commanders and to Service and DOD Components. Ad hoc reports based on patient data. Medical unit readiness reporting and aggregation capability (Annex Q reporting). Key Benefits: Common operational picture that combines medical facility readiness and status information displaying on a map. Symptom-based disease detection Customizable disease surveillance. Diagnosis-based disease detection and Disease Non Battle Injuries (DNBI) with Automated DNBI reporting. Enhances situational awareness and decision making for Joint Planners and Command Control Staff. Displays data that is required by planners and operational staff at respective levels. Key Issues: Training, SIPR Availability, Awareness, Data Quality.

asset.name: C - BHIE
asset.description: Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) is a secure real time display of viewable health data between DOD/VA. Allows DOD and VA providers to view clinical information in real time for patients who receive care in either agency health system.
asset.significance: Key Features: Encounters/clinical notes. Problem lists, procedures and diagnoses. Vital signs. Outpatient medications, laboratory results, radiology reports and allergies. Theater level clinical data from TMDS. Inpatient documentation from Essentris. Family histories and social histories, and other histories. Questionnaires. Key Benefits: Enhance the provision of care to Wounded Warriors. Reduce the need to exchange paper records with the VA. Enhance the delivery of patient care. Enhance readiness. Increase clinical and administrative efficiency. Key Issues: Training, Awareness.

asset.name: B-F1 - AHLTA-Mobile F1-1
asset.description: In-field medics may also use hand-held Android based devices running the data application AHLTA-Mobile to document related medical information that can be transferred to AHLTA-T.
asset.significance: Point of injury clinical documentation (now including traumatic brain injury).Health history information, including allergies and medical readiness data. Medical references (pharmacy library, Thomson Clinical Reference). Data feed to AHLTA-Theater. Key Benefits: Helps ensure accuracy of information with automated medical coding. Enables providers to access information at any location supporting the highest level of care. Improves visibility of documented Level 1 care. Key Issues: Training, Battery Life, Durability.

asset.name: C-F1 - AHLTA-Theater F1-1
asset.description: AHLTA-Theater enables digitally documentation of patient care with use of a MC4 Windows based laptop or client-server environment, with store-and-forward capabilities meaning data is first stored in a local database then later transferred through internet connectivity.
asset.significance: Key Features: Low and no communication environment (store and forward). Interfaces with SAMS, TC2 and AHLTAMobile Bed and Order Management. Theater Admin/Theater Security (create clinics, manage users). Able to import patient demographic data from Authoritative Data Source. Drug-Drug/Drug-Allergy interaction screening. Alternate input method. Key Benefits: Improve system availability, reliability and sustainability. Enhance the delivery of patient care. Enhance the ability to provide complete and accurate of documentation of patient care at every echelon of care. Key Issues: Training, Connectivity, Duplicate Patients, First Responder Documentation.

asset.name: B-F1 - Field Medic - Holds Info
asset.description: The Medic has holds first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information may be transferred and written to a FMC-TCCC, input on a mobile handset, be verbally transmitted via radio communications and in-person to Air Medics.
asset.significance: The Medic has holds first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information may be transferred and written to a FMC-TCCC, input on a mobile handset, be verbally transmitted via radio communications and in-person to Air Medics. Without the availability and transfer of this information, patient care may be affected.

asset.name: C-F1 - Air Medic - Holds Info
asset.description: In addition to Field Medic patient info, the Air Medic will hold first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information is likely to include a written FMC-TCCC, and verbal field medic communication, and further continuing care information.
asset.significance: In addition to Field Medic patient info, the Air Medic will hold first-hand knowledge of patient care. This information is likely to include a written FMC-TCCC, and verbal field medic communication, and further continuing care information. Without the availability and transfer of this information, patient care may be affected, and health records may become incorrect.

asset.name: C-F2 - FST Technician - Holds Info
asset.description: A FST Technician will receive and hold verbal patient information from the Air Medic and usually a copy of the FMC-TCCC. Once received, this is communicated to a medical team, and input through AHLTA-Theater to the patient EHR.
asset.significance: A FST Technician will receive and hold verbal patient information from the Air Medic and usually a copy of the FMC-TCCC. Once received, this is communicated to a medical team, and input through AHLTA-Theater to the patient EHR. Immediate availability of this information is important, along with the integrity of input data.

threatened_property.name: confidentiality
threatened_property.rationale: The data is produced by a medic about a patient. This information is usually past along with the patient via an air medic and on to the FST, and other stage hospitals when required, but should be accessed only by relevant staff proving patient care.

threatened_property.name: integrity
threatened_property.rationale: Integrity of the data must be maintained to ensure correct patient information is clear and recordable.

threatened_property.name: availability
threatened_property.rationale: In some cases a FMC - TCCC may not be completed due to time constraints. However, where this is used, it is very useful towards accurate accounting of initial and continuing care.

threatened_property.name: accountability
threatened_property.rationale: Bravo is responsible for the creation and retention of a copy of the FMC - TCCC information. However, continuing care providers Charlie have accountability towards maintaining its on-going PST, where Alpha have accountability towards the operational network data is shared within.

asset_association.head_name: C-F1 - Air-Med MC4 Laptop - Patient Info

asset_association.tail_name: C-F1 - Air Medic - Written Patient Info

persona.name: Mr Field Medic
persona.activities: Patrols trek through mountainous terrain. Provide humanitarian and first aid for citizens as well. Work on the front line, saving soldiers and attending to locals. Get casualties off the battlefield as quickly and safely as possible. Assess and treat casualty. Call for MEDEVAC. Document care. Transfer patient and information to MEDEVAC. Upload patient data. Donates toys to sick children.
persona.attitudes: Does all he can for casualties. Need to be brave and determined. Demonstrate to locals we care. Field medics are first point of care. It is hard to work on the kids, especially the young ones. Language and cultural barriers towards treatment in some cases. Locals are casualties of IEDs also. Treating children and burns is common.
persona.aptitudes: Constant learning. Stay calm in the heat of battle and give emergency treatment.
persona.motivations: Getting casualties off the battlefield as quickly and safely as possible. Saving lives. Helping the locals.
persona.skills: Trained as a soldier, attached as a trained combat medical technician. Trained to stabilise patients for evacuation.

persona_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
persona_environment.narrative: As a Field Medic, saving peoples lives is all part of the job. It is also about the humanitarian effort with locals, who themselves are frequent casualties of IEDs, often children, which is hard to deal with at times. Nevertheless, tending to their medical needs and calling for their medical evacuation is a priority. the clock starts ticking at Point of Injury (PoI). The first hour of field and air care is critical. The patient and information is transferred to MEDEVAC and further information is later uploaded to the central repository. Humanitarian and first aid continues to be applied to others.

persona_environment.name: All Systems (Overview)
persona_environment.narrative: As a Field Medic, saving peoples lives is all part of the job. It is also about the humanitarian effort with locals, who themselves are frequent casualties of IEDs, often children, which is hard to deal with at times. Nevertheless, tending to their medical needs and calling for their medical evacuation is a priority. the clock starts ticking at Point of Injury (PoI). The first hour of field and air care is critical. The patient and information is transferred to MEDEVAC and further information is later uploaded to the central repository. Humanitarian and first aid continues to be applied to others.

persona.name: Miss Air Medic
persona.activities: Prepares equipment for MEDEVAC. Quick turnaround for calls. Is called to a mixed range of casualties in many locations. Lands is hostile environments. Transfers patient and documentation. Treats casualty in air on the way to hospital, documenting care. Transfers patient and information of care given to FST. Complete documenting care and upload data to central repository within 24hrs. Prepare for next MEDEVAC call out. Always on call. Mental preparation checklists.
persona.attitudes: Care given pre-hospital contributes to survival. In-air activities are complex. Documenting information can be complex. AHLTA software input is too detailed. People often misconceive what MEDEVAC do. Always see the worst days for people. Anticipation of a call is the worst part of the job. Have to be on A game. Lack of focus can affect the patient. Quick re-focus for next mission.
persona.skills: Trained as a soldier, attached as a trained air medical technician.

persona_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
persona_environment.narrative: As an Air Medic, the work is high-stress with a quick turnaround to fly to patients in hostile terrains, evacuating them to a hospital providing treatment en route. Treatment to different nationality casualties of differing ages can be a challenge along with the complex care provided and documented. Care provided and the speed in which they are taken to FST is critical to a patients survival and the continuum of care.

persona_environment.name: All Systems (Overview)
persona_environment.narrative: As an Air Medic, the work is high-stress with a quick turnaround to fly to patients in hostile terrains, evacuating them to a hospital providing treatment en route. Treatment to different nationality casualties of differing ages can be a challenge along with the complex care provided and documented. Care provided and the speed in which they are taken to FST is critical to a patients survival and the continuum of care.

persona.name: Mr TOC Officer
persona.activities: The TOC handles calls for MEDEVAC of patients. Use of a variety of communications technologies. Contacts PECC regarding request. Call for the Air MEDEVAC. Co-ordinate ISR for MEDEVAC missions. JChat is used to update trauma teams. JChat provides an audit trail.
persona.attitudes: Bases often get rocket attacks. Lots of calls resulting from IEDs. TOC has access to many networks. Having the right Situational Awareness increases combat effectiveness. The AMN is important for ISR and communication. Without the AMN immediate communication would be reduced. JChat is an integral part of the the AMN. Managing too many Chat rooms creates inefficiency and confusion. Using JChat is less prone to jamming or friendly force interference. Using JChat provides greater clarity when communicating. Trust in MEDEAVC is an important factor.
persona.skills: Trained as a soldier. Trained in combat planning and co-ordination.

persona_environment.name: All Systems (Overview)
persona_environment.narrative: As the Tactical Operations Centre Officer, one of the main duties is to monitor ISR for incoming and on-going calls for MEDEVAC operation, co-ordinating with PECC for the continuum of care. The TOC Officer receives a 9-Line request for a MEDEVAC, organise the request through PECC, calls the Air MEDEVAC and monitors ISR for evacuations to FST and other operations.

persona.name: Ms FST Technician
persona.activities: Receives casualties from MEDEVAC for continuing care. Can be locals or soldiers. Transfers patient information. Further documents on-going patient information, some of which is input and uploaded to the central repository. Battlefield injuries are usually IEDs.
persona.attitudes: Bases often get rocket attacks. Battlefield injuries are usually IEDs. IEDs cause limb amputations with severe injuries. Casualties in FST can be personal. Different emergency care than in home world care. Good pre-hospital care can increase quality of life. Sometimes notice is given upon arrival of casualty to FST. We meet a lot of people on the worst day of their life. Patients are confused from injuries. Sometimes it is clear what injury takes priority. There are some things you cannot un-see. Sometimes patients die. In FST the room smells like damp earth, rubbing alcohol and blood. Staff choose to work in this environment. No going home, only long-distance phone calls and conversations over Skype. The soldiers do the important work, FST have it easy. There are no designated breaks or no nights off at FST. Time keeping and patient care is important.
persona.motivations: Saving lives. Treating diverse injuries helps learning and improving.
persona.skills: Trained a s a soldier. Trained in hospital trauma. Specifically familiar with battlefield injuries, usually IEDs.

persona_environment.name: All Systems (Overview)
persona_environment.narrative: As a Forward Surgical Team Technician, receiving and treating incoming casualties from MEDEVAC is the priority. Pre-hospital care was equally important, as is the documentation and information transfer of care given. This is used to apply further on-going documented care, which is uploaded to the central repository forming the EHR.

persona.name: Mrs PECC Assistant
persona.activities: PECC co-ordinates and communicates with many stakeholders, e.g. hospitals, ATM... PECCs main focus is on ISAF but provide assistance to ANSF. The PECC goal is to provide the quickest most effective MEDEVAC.
persona.attitudes: Bases often get rocket attacks. All elements of PECC need to work effectively. PECC co-ordination requires a lot of communication. PECC needs to ensure everyone is well supported. The PECC is very much a team-based approach. It is our duty to the soldiers to provide necessary help.
persona.aptitudes: Co-ordination of all aspects of MEDEVAC requires an intimate knowledge.
persona.motivations: Pride in professionalism and care given. It is an honour to support those in the battlefield.
persona.skills: Trained as a soldier. Trained to have an intimate knowledge of all aspects of MEDEVAC.

persona_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
persona_environment.narrative: As a Patient Evacuation Co-ordination Cell Assistant, organising the patient and MEDEVAC continuum of care is a critical operation. Confirmation of a MEDEVAC request comes in from TOC. This is then processed allowing for the request to be actioned, arranging hospital and on-going patient care and tracking. The PECC pride themselves on contributing towards saving lives through the continuum of care.

persona_environment.name: All Systems (Overview)
persona_environment.narrative: As a Patient Evacuation Co-ordination Cell Assistant, organising the patient and MEDEVAC continuum of care is a critical operation. Confirmation of a MEDEVAC request comes in from TOC. This is then processed allowing for the request to be actioned, arranging hospital and on-going patient care and tracking. The PECC pride themselves on contributing towards saving lives through the continuum of care.

persona.attitudes: Has a bad attitude towards life.
persona.aptitudes: Has high intelligence, but warped reality.

persona.name: Mr Patient
persona.aptitudes: Pain and injuries remove norms as survival kicks-in.
persona.skills: Pain and injuries remove norms as survival kicks-in.

persona_environment.name: Charlie (Ops View)
persona_environment.narrative: In most cases, a person becomes a casualty of an IED explosion or other explosive wounds and burns, placing life and limbs at risk, requiring medical treatment and evacuation.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Always see the worst days for people
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: We always see the worst days for people,

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Traumatic
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: generally the worst day of someone's life.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Medevac is a roller coaster of emotions
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Medevac operations are a roller coaster of emotions, swinging from hours of overwhelming boredom to explosions of frenzied activity every time the radio crackles "Medevac! Medevac! Medevac!"

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Anticipation of a call is the worst part of the job
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: It's the sitting around, knowing something might happen at any time, but you don't know what it's going to be or how serious

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Team work
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: fast-paced, but well-choreographed

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Mental preparation checklists
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: each member of the crew runs down an internal checklist, mentally and physically preparing for what they're all about to head in to. Oftentimes, however, medevac crews don't know.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Diversity of challenges
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: That's the thing that's interesting about this job," said Heaston. "Once you get a POI [point-of-injury] call, you have no clue what you're getting into until you're there. They're all different.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Diversity of locations
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: We've been all over this area of Afghanistan -- farmers' fields, highways -- you name it, we've been there.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Unsettled work area
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: In the back of a helicopter being tossed seemingly in every direction all at once by heavy winds

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Prepare for the worst
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: You kind of just hope for the best and prepare for the worst

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM For the benefit of the patient
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: He might not like what I'm doing, and it might not feel good, but it's for his benefit, to make him feel better.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Need to stay focused
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: The only thing on my mind is I have to do what it takes to make him feel better, and I can't let myself get side-tracked or start thinking about other things

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Lack of focus can affect the patient
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: You can't let that other stuff bother you, or it affects what you're doing for the patient."

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Patient pain reduction and reassurance
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: You want them to know you're doing everything you can to make them feel better -- to take away the pain," said Gibson, "and to reassure them they're on their way to the hospital, and the doctors there are going to do everything they can to give them the best possible outcome

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM You can not let every scenario personally affect you
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: You can't let every scenario personally affect you,

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Need to switch off after FST and re-focus
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: else your job's really going to get to you and it's going to be harder for you to do. I mean, to some extent, it's going to, but you just have to kind of compartmentalize, and as soon as you take him to the FST (hospital), you know he's in the best hands he can be in, and you've just got to kind of let that be the end of it.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Quick re-focus for next mission
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: You have to put your focus back on putting your aircraft together and getting ready for the next mission, should it come.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Have to be on A game
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: We go from dead asleep to flying in our most dangerous mode of flight in just eight minutes, so you have to get your 'A' game on really quickly,

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Saving lives matters
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: It's a call no one wants to hear, but helping a wounded Soldier on the battlefield is the only thing that matters to medevac crews.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Always on call
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: But when it comes, it comes. I'm always here to do my job, no matter what time of day or night it is. Sometimes I think, 'It's three in the morning, why am I running to a helicopter?' But that's our job, and you just get out and you do it.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Every person cares about the mission
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Every single person in our unit cares so much about the mission

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Rewarding impact
document_reference.document: Best Soldiers for the worst days: Medevac crews in Afghanistan save lives day, night | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Every day you know you made an impact on someone's life. It's amazing to be able to feel that way

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Complex information to document
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: As flight medics, we chart a lot of advanced, critical procedures that is

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Complex activities of air care
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: We’re doing more than applying a tourniquet, giving patients morphine and taking them to the next facility.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM AHLTA software input is too detailed
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: The problem with the outpatient software on the laptop, AHLTA-T, is that it wants us to enter information that is too detailed for our mission. This is great in a clinic setting for doctors, but it doesn’t work well for flight medics.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Information flow and timelines of treatment is important to the role
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: For pre-hospital care, just about everything we do is based off of a primary and secondary survey, a narrative and then a timeline with the medications and treatments given at specific times.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Document care en route and communicate
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: We transcribe the patient information and our treatments to the form while we’re en route to the hospital. When we arrive at the treatment facility, we give the facility staff a verbal report based off our paper forms.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Add data to laptops and upload within 24hrs
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: Our standard is that medevac personnel are to enter the data from the PCR into MC4 within 24 hours from patient contact. Typically, the information is entered after the flight medic’s shift.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM All information input may not be complete by the time the patient is transferred for other care
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: Because of the efficiency of the hospital staff, it is not uncommon for the patient to be on a plane bound for Germany for additional care as the information from the PCR is entered into MC4. Our documentation might not be available electronically when the doctors and nurses in Afghanistan begin treating the patient, but we want to make sure that when the wounded warrior arrives in Germany, the medical staff has the full medical picture and can see what the flight medics did and observed.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Believes there is a misconception what medevac does
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: I think that many people believe that a medevac consists of putting injured personnel on a helicopter, the pilots fly very fast to the hospital and little care is given en route.

document_reference.name: C-F1-AM Flight times can range from 20 to 60 minutes
document_reference.document: MC4 News
document_reference.excerpt: In Afghanistan, due to the remote locations where missions are conducted and the location of treatment facilities, flight times can range from 20 to 60 minutes.

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Field medics are first point of care
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: On the frontlines, medics stabilize severely-wounded troops long enough for a medical evacuation to a field hospital.

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Medical care provided to soldiers and locals
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: use their medical skills for not only their fellow Soldiers but also local Afghans

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Demonstrate to locals we care
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: The impression we try to leave is that America is here to help them in their lives and not to hurt them in any kind of way

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Patrols trek through mountainous terrain
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Most of the patrols trek through mountainous terrain to local villages

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM We provide humanitarian and first aid for citizens as well
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: When we're on patrol we provide aid -- humanitarian aid or first aid for citizens

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Treating children and burns is common
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Burns, especially among children, are the most common injuries that the medics see in the remote villages

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Locals are casualties of IEDs also
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: IEDs are bad

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Trained to stabilise patients for evacuation
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: trained to insert chest tubes and sew sutures at a NATO-sponsored medical patrol course in Germany, he should be able to stabilize wounded Soldiers and civilians up to 72 hours, while waiting for evacuation

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Language and cultural barriers towards treatment in some cases
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: Both medics believe the language barrier makes treating civilians difficult. Both try to read the body language of their patients, as well as demonstrate through their own body language their purpose to help. They always work with an interpreter, but there is no guarantee of an exact translation,

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM It is hard to work on the kids, especially the young ones
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Donates toys to sick children
document_reference.document: Combat medics treat Afghan locals, provide healthcare to remote villages | Article | The United States Army
document_reference.excerpt: occasionally receive care packages, sometimes with toys in them. The medics hand out these toys to comfort an ill or hurting child being treated

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM I do all I can for casualties
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: Give first aid on the battlefield. Provide medical training to the Army. Supply medical support on all kinds of operations and exercises. Help with medical evacuations in hostile conditions. Provide health education to the Army

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Work on the front line, saving soldiers
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: work on the front line, saving soldiers

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Stay calm in the heat of battle and give emergency treatment
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: Stay calm in the heat of battle and give emergency treatment

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Get casualties off the battlefield as quickly and safely as possible
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: Get casualties off the battlefield as quickly and safely as possible

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Brave and determined
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: brave and determined

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Constant learning
document_reference.document: Combat Medical Technician - British Army
document_reference.excerpt: work under the expert guidance of doctors in medical centres, or in front-line bases, which can have difficult working conditions

document_reference.name: B-F1-FM Attach FMC-TCCC to patient
document_reference.excerpt: Once completed, DD Form 1380 must be visibly attached to the patient. Upon arrival at a Role 2 or Role 3 MTF, DD Form 1380 will be included with the paper medical record, then canned and entered into both the patient’s electronic health record and the trauma system’s trauma registry. http://www.esd.whs.mil/Portals/54/Documents/DD/forms/dd/dd1380inst.pdf

document_reference.name: A-T-TO The TOC handles inbound patients
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: (TOC) fed by several networks that coordinate medical treatment amidst the chaos of combat. The TOC handles inbound patients.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Use of a variety of communications technologies
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: teams use a variety of communications technologies, including the nonsecure Internet protocol router network; the NATO Secret Network, which is the heart of the Afghan Mission Network; a NATO chat function known as JChat; and more traditional tactical radios

document_reference.name: A-T-TO TOC has access to many networks
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: I think they’ve got roughly seven networks in this one room that covers all the communications modalities they need to cover

document_reference.name: A-T-TO JChat is used to update trauma teams
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: monitors Mission Secret, which is the classified system, watching JChat—that online chat room—all day long. He’ll notify our trauma teams to let them know what’s inbound. He’ll give them the details of the injuries, if we get that, and he’ll notify the rest of the staff so we can dispatch members to the flight line

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Notice of casualty arrival at FST within 15 minutes
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: Usually, the hospital staff will have up to 15 minutes’ notice before medevac helicopters arrive, but that is not always the case.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Sometimes notice is given upon arrival of casualty to FST
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: There are times when we get the word that alphas are inbound now, now, now. The helos are almost on our door, and we’re scrambling to be there when the helos land because we do not want to be the delay factor. We’ve got to be there to get them

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT People who work at FST are high-speed low-drag
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: To be honest, most people who work here are high-speed, low-drag. There’s little they cannot do themselves. Rarely do they have to reach back and consult on a case

document_reference.name: Patient - Casualties of IEDs
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: One group of soldiers on a dismounted patrol encountered an improvised explosive device

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Survival rate for coalition forces is increased by medic care
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: A big part of our ability to maintain a 97 percent survival rate for coalition forces truly is the people in the field—the medics

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Good pre-hospital care can increase quality of life
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: We had one patient come in here, a triple amputee. When he got here, the tourniquets were all applied. He was wide awake. He was talking to us, telling us what he had for breakfast. He was giving us his name, his background history. His blood pressure was 120 over 80. That’s amazing

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Kinetic energy from IEDs shakes things up internally in patients
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: You can imagine the kinetic energy from improvised explosive devices and so forth. Yes, it rips off legs, but all that energy really shakes things up internally—things you just don’t see in your normal life

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Time keeping and patient care is important
document_reference.document: A Lot of Blood in Kandahar | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: clocks throughout the building are synchronized, which is important when precision timing and coordination mean life or death

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Chat capabilities offer several advantages over voice communications
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: Chat capabilities offer several advantages over voice communications

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Using JChat provides greater clarity when communicating
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: providing greater clarity when communicators speak different languages or dialects;

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Using JChat is less prone to jamming or friendly force interference
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: being less prone to jamming or friendly force interference; and offering quieter, stealthier communication for troops in tense situations,

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Too many Chat rooms can become cumbersome
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: But thousands of chat rooms available to warfighters have proven to be too much of a good thing.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Radio transmissions may not be clear
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: On a broken radio transmission or a hard-to-hear telephone transmission in a high-stress environment, you may not be able to understand what that other person is saying

document_reference.name: A-T-TO In JChat, text is right in front of you and you can read it
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: With text, it’s right in front of you and you can read it, so that’s a real benefit to chat in a coalition environment.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO JChat provides an audit trail
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: chat also offers a record of what was happened during a specific incident.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Managing too many Chat rooms creates inefficiency and confusion.
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: Chat has become so popular for conducting battlefield operations, however, that the number of rooms available has reached into the thousands, creating inefficiency and confusion.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO JChat is an integral part of the the AMN
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: One of the most widely used chat capabilities in Afghanistan is a joint tool known as JChat, which is provided by the NATO Consultation, Command and Control Agency. It has become an integral part of the Afghan Mission Network—the core network for conducting operations in the war theater.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO The AMN is important for ISR and communication
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: the network continually proves its value in part by giving units on the battlefield a reliable connection back to the Coalition Joint Operations Center (CJOC). “Every night, or every day, you have combat operations, and it creates what we call ‘troops in contact.’ In those instances, those nations that have troops in contact now have connectivity back to the CJOC, so the CJOC can turn resources—whether intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance or combat aviation resources or medevac—to help accomplish those missions going on out there.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Without the AMN immediate communication would be reduced
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: Without that capability, he explains, every single one of those troops-in-contact incidents would involve one person calling in information, which would have to be carefully jotted down, passed along and physically input into the various individual networks.

document_reference.name: A-T-TO Having the right Situational Awareness increases combat effectiveness
document_reference.document: Military Treats Outbreak of Chat Rooms in Afghanistan | SIGNAL Magazine
document_reference.excerpt: The increase in combat effectiveness is directly related to the fact that we’re all using the same information from the beginning. We’re not all asking if this is the right grid, the right unit, the right enemy, the right villag

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC interacts with many stakeholders
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: The joint forces team that makes up the Patient Evacuation Coordination Cell coordinates all medical and tactical evacuations across three provinces in southern Afghanistan for Regional Command (South), and assists in requested Afghan National Security Force medical operations.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Co-ordination of all aspects of MEDEVAC requires an intimate knowledge
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: The coordination of all aspects of MEDEVAC and TACEVAC requires an intimate knowledge of current operations, medical treatment facility status, weather status, aircraft status and maintenance issues

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC co-ordination requires a lot of communication
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: To coordinate a typical medical mission, the PECC is in constant communication with all military air and ground assets that have a role in assuring the evacuation goes smoothly and quickly

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC is very much a team-based approach
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: It is very much a team-based approach

document_reference.name: A-P-PA All elements of PECC need to work effectively
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: All elements need to work effectively

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC needs to ensure everyone is well supported
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: need to work effectively to ensure everyone is well supported

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Communication increases patient survival
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: keeping all elements informed throughout the process offers the best chance for damage control and increases the patient’s chance for survival.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Pride in professionalism and care given
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: We pride ourselves on the professionalism of our team and the sense of commitment to ensure the fastest, most suitable care is given to soldiers

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECCs main focus is on ISAF but provide assistance to ANSF
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: While the PECC’s main focus is to support International Security Assistance Force medical missions, they also work closely with the ANSF Operational Coordination Center (Regional South), a regional hub for ANSF pillars, as they continue to establish a medical common operating picture, to support and assist in ANSF medical operations

document_reference.name: A-P-PA It is an honour to support those in the battlefield
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: I don’t think there is any greater honor on the battlefield than being able to support those who are injured

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Trust in MEDEAVC is an important factor
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: Knowing that all troops on ground have the faith and confidence in the MEDEVAC asset we provide and trust that MEDEVAC process ensures that we can get them the highest level of care.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC goal is to provide the quickest most effective MEDEVAC
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: Each of the ISAF nations’ most important resources are the soldiers. Our goal here in the PECC is to provide the quickest most effective MEDEVAC to the soldier fighting the fight and conducting the missions outside the wire

document_reference.name: A-P-PA It is our duty to the soldiers to provide necessary help
document_reference.document: DVIDS - News - Medical operations in Afghanistan: Continued success as ANSF takes the lead
document_reference.excerpt: We owe it to them to do whatever is necessary to coordinate the resources required to help them

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT In FST the room smells like damp earth, rubbing alcohol and blood
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: The room smells like damp earth, rubbing alcohol and blood

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Many traumas arrive at FST
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: "The stuff you hear about now – it's all troop withdrawals and winding down." He closes his eyes for a moment and rubs them. It's been a while since he slept. "All I can say is we got 19 new traumas yesterday. Nothing is winding …" He's interrupted by the beeping of the pager that never leaves his side. He unclips it from his waist and reads the message. "IED blast," he says. "Three patients en route."

document_reference.name: AC-TPF2-TOPAFT Bases often get rocket attacks
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: in the heart of Taliban country at Kandahar Airfield, a sprawling, heavily fortified southern NATO base that's attacked with rockets so routinely that no one bothers to panic anymore when the sirens sound

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Battlefield injuries are usually IEDs
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: patients come directly from the battlefield, the vast majority of them victims of insurgent-made bombs – what the military calls improvised explosive devices, or IEDs.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT IEDs cause limb amputations with severe injuries
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Their signature wounds are double- and triple- limb amputations with severe injuries to the pelvis and genitals

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Experienced at treating IED injuries
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: We can't do everything. We can't treat cancer. But when it comes to war injuries – to IEDs, to gunshot wounds – I believe we are the very best there is

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Different emergency care than in home world care
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: If these soldiers landed in the same condition at any major hospital back home instead of here, there is no doubt in my mind that many more of them would not live

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Patients usually arrive by air and can be locals or soldiers
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Patients come from across Afghanistan's southern half, almost always by helicopter because of the steep surrounding mountains, the dangers of traveling by road and the need to get them here fast. In addition to coalition soldiers, they include Afghan civilians, members of the Afghan national army and police, and enemy combatants wounded in the fighting.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Treating diverse injuries helps learning and improving
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: When you see the same things day in and day out – patients with two or three extremities blown off, with really bad burns or almost all their blood gone – you get very good at treating it,

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Sometimes it is clear what injury takes priority
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Sometimes it's clear what injury takes priority – the missing arm or the hemorrhaging femoral artery. Sometimes the worst wounds are hidden – internal bleeding or a snapped third vertebra. Some patients are unconscious. Others are excruciatingly aware.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Patients are confused from injuries
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: He is usually groggy and confused with little recollection of how he got here. His eyes search for a person. They settle on a doctor or a nurse. And then he strains to ask whatever question comes to his mind first. Where am I? How long have I been here? Will I walk again? Do I still have knees? For those who are there to answer, none of it ever feels routine.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT We meet a lot of people on the worst day of their life
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: We meet a lot of people on the worst day of their life

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Staff choose to work in this environment
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Most of the staff volunteered for this. They trained for it. They asked colleagues who've done tours here what to expect.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT On good days, it is pulling nails and rocks from the wounds
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: On good days, it is pulling nails and rocks from the wounds of a soldier who still has all four limbs. It is taking the crumpled piece of paper he has carried on every patrol, dialing the scribbled numbers, and handing him the phone so he can hear his girlfriend's voice

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Sometimes patients die
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Other days, it is unfolding a flag and draping it over a body. It is standing at attention on the tarmac outside as nine caskets are loaded onto a U.S.-bound cargo plane.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT There are some things you cannot un-see
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: There are some things you can't un-see

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT There are no designated breaks or no nights off at FST.
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: There are no designated breaks, no nights off. If it sounds bad enough when the staffwide page goes out, everybody drops what they're doing – showering, sleeping, working out at the gym across base – and literally runs to beat the helicopter.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Time loses meaning, it becomes a blur
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Time loses meaning unless it's counting down to a patient's arrival; days and weeks tend to blur into one another, because at the end of a shift, there is no going home.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT No going home, only long-distance phone calls and conversations over Skype
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: There are only long-distance phone calls and conversations over Skype in which they brush past questions from husbands and wives about what they did that day. They all learn early on that trying to explain it only causes worry, and the people on the other end never know what to say anyway.

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT The soldiers do the important work, FST have it easy
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: What we're doing in here, inside this hospital, this is nothing. You see the stuff we see and all you can really think is, 'I've got it good. I've got it easy

document_reference.name: C-F2-FT Casualties in FST can be personal
document_reference.document: A chance in hell, part 1 | Inside a combat hospital in Afghanistan | Afghanistan | pilotonline.com
document_reference.excerpt: Then you start to think about everything that lies ahead for him, assuming he survives. You think about how he's going to feel when he wakes up after this surgery and realizes that it wasn't all a nightmare. You think about how it will hit him all over again just as hard after the next operation. And the next. And the next. You wonder whether he has a wife. You wonder what he'll say when he makes the first phone call home, and what the person on the other end will say back. You think about the long recovery, all the rehab, the prosthesis. You wonder what he dreamed about doing after the Army and whether he'll still be able to do it. Then you realize you've seen him before. "I recognize this guy from the gym," says one of the staff who is about to operate on him.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Best care for survival within Golden Hour
document_reference.document: Military Medical Teams Get Troops Off the Battlefield and On the Road to Recovery United Service Organizations
document_reference.excerpt: Most providers say that if you get the best care to that patient within that frame of time they have the greatest chance of making it to the next site … to get continued care

document_reference.name: C-F2-AM MEDEVAC importance
document_reference.document: Military Medical Teams Get Troops Off the Battlefield and On the Road to Recovery United Service Organizations
document_reference.excerpt: all of a sudden it becomes us who [have] the most important job, because we’ve got to then take that patient from the point of injury or the hospital to the next level of care.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC is a MEDEVAC and regulating C2
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC is a MEDEVAC and regulating C2 node used within each regional (and theater) command for current operations. The PECC greatly enhances the coordination and execution of MEDEVAC in an Allied Environment. The Patient Evacuation Co-ordination Cell By CPT Anthony L. Leiding Aviation Digest USArmy Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 http://www.dustoff.org/Old-news/Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC is staffed and operated 24/7 and approves all MEDEVAC requests
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC is staffed 24-7 and approves all MEDEVAC requests
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC is staffed and operated 24-7 and assigns mission approval authority to all MEDEVAC requests.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC joint-force collaboration offers advantages
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC offers many advantages to the MEDEVAC system by nature of their location within the Joint Operations Center (JOC) and their ability to oversee all intra-theater MEDEVAC assets within the area of operations. The location of the PECC in the JOC provides instant access to the decision making authorities for high-risk mission approval authority.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC are able to readily co-ordinate with stakeholders
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: PECC personnel are able to readily coordinate with aviation, fires, and other functional areas within the JOC.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC maintains medical COP
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC also maintains the medical common operating picture for their area of operations and can task other types of evacuation platforms, such as ground ambulances, if conditions dictate via the 9-line MEDEVAC request.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA PECC monitors real-time patient status
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC monitors all MTF bed statuses and evacuation platforms operational readiness rates to enable real-time status for optimal decision making resulting in the best possible patient outcomes.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA The PECC has situational awareness to prioritise and synchronize
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: The PECC has the situational awareness to prioritize or combine patient transfer requests depending on patient condition. They synchronize the medical evacuation system to most effectively provide the patient with the right care by the most efficient means.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Training for PECC is essential
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: Codifying, manning, and training a PECC is essential as we continue to synchronize joint medical assets in order to ensure the best patient outcomes for our service members.

document_reference.name: A-P-PA Good staffing ensures effective MEDEVAC
document_reference.document: Aviation Digest US Army Oct-Dec 2014 V2 Issue 4 Avn Digest Oct-Dec_100114.pdf
document_reference.excerpt: A properly staffed, trained, and integrated PECC will ensure that our MEDEVAC system is most effectively allocated.

task.name: Gain medical assistance
task.author: D
task.objective: The in-field casualty requires medical assistance.

task_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
task_environment.dependencies: Dependent initially by a Field Medic, but then by each stage of the continuum of care.
task_environment.narrative: The person (military or civilian) is injured and requires immediate medical attention.
task_environment.consequences: Without assistance there is a risk to life.
task_environment.benefits: Immediate medical attention may reduce risk to life.

task.name: Provide and document medical care during MEDEVAC
task.author: D
task.objective: The Air Medic is required to provide and document medical assistance to the in-field casualty during MEDEVAC.

task_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
task_environment.dependencies: This depends on many factors, including Air Traffic management. Correct details of location and casualty in the 9 Line request is important to be maintained from TOC and PECC. There is a dependence on systems securely working, e.g. radios, laptops.
task_environment.narrative: A casualty is attended to by a Field Medic who assesses the injury and calls for a MEDEVAC. The TOC and PECC initiate the Air MEDEVAC who fly to and retrieve the casualty. The FMC-TCCC is sent along the patient journey with the Air Medic. On-going care is provided whilst en-route to the FST. Patient information including FMC-TCCC details are discussed with the FST Technician and later added to the MC4 Air Medic Laptop then uploaded to the TMDS data repository.
task_environment.consequences: This task is required to provide initial care for a casualty. If this is not conducted, there is a risk to life. If care is not documented and accessible for continuing care, this may affect or delay patient care.
task_environment.benefits: Patient care is given to reduce risk to life.

task.name: Arrange MEDEAVC and patient care
task.author: D
task.objective: The PECC Assistant is to arrange the MEDEVAC and continuum of care.

task_environment.name: Alpha (Mgmt View)
task_environment.dependencies: The 9-Line request must be communicated correctly and clearly. TOC and PECC must co-ordinate to ensure the safe operation of MEDEVAC. There is a dependence on systems securely working, e.g. radios, JChat, ISR, and Air Traffic Management.
task_environment.narrative: A Field Medic has assessed a casualty and uses a 9-Line request to call for MEDEVAC. This is received by the TOC who contacts PECC, and together organise the MEDEVAC. The TOC also relies on ISR to support the MEDEVAC, and adds some patient information to JChat for advance information to support FST. The PECC are directly accountable towards organising the on-going continuum of care.
task_environment.consequences: Without this organisation, the MEDEVAC SoS is ineffective, causing risk to life. Continuing care also has to be managed appropriately to ensure a continuum of care.
task_environment.benefits: With this organisation, the MEDEVAC SoS provides a continuum of care.

task_environment.name: Charlie (Ops View)
task_environment.dependencies: The 9-Line request must be communicated correctly and clearly. TOC and PECC must co-ordinate to ensure the safe operation of MEDEVAC. There is a dependence on systems securely working, e.g. radios, JChat, ISR, and Air Traffic Management.
task_environment.narrative: A Field Medic has assessed a casualty and uses a 9-Line request to call for MEDEVAC. This is received by the TOC who contacts PECC, and together organise the MEDEVAC. The TOC also relies on ISR to support the MEDEVAC, and adds some patient information to JChat for advance information to support FST. The PECC are directly accountable towards organising the on-going continuum of care.
task_environment.consequences: Without this organisation, the the MEDEVAC SoS is ineffective, causing risk to life. Continuing care also has to be managed appropriately to ensure a continuum of care.
task_environment.benefits: With this organisation, the MEDEVAC SoS provides a continuum of care.

task_environment.name: Bravo (Ops View)
task_environment.dependencies: The 9-Line request must be communicated correctly and clearly. TOC and PECC must co-ordinate to ensure the safe operation of MEDEVAC. There is a dependence on systems securely working, e.g. radios, JChat, ISR, and Air Traffic Management.
task_environment.narrative: A Field Medic has assessed a casualty and uses a 9-Line request to call for MEDEVAC. This is received by the TOC who contacts PECC, and together organise the MEDEVAC. The TOC also relies on ISR to support the MEDEVAC, and adds some patient information to JChat for advance information to support FST. The PECC are directly accountable towards organising the on-going continuum of care.
task_environment.consequences: Without this organisation, the the MEDEVAC SoS is ineffective, causing risk to life. Continuing care also has to be managed appropriately to ensure a continuum of care.
task_environment.benefits: With this organisation, the MEDEVAC SoS provides a continuum of care.
